questions.question: A 4-year-old with newly diagnosed acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) has pallor, frequent nosebleeds, and recurrent infections. These manifestations are most directly related to which pathophysiologic effect?
options: Hypertension, bradycardia, and hypothermia
Polyuria, polydipsia, and polyphagia
Anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia from bone marrow failure
Weight gain, edema, and moon face from steroid therapy

questions.question: A child with ALL is being discussed on rounds. Which factor is considered favorable for prognosis?
options: Age at diagnosis less than 1 year
Age between 2 and 10 years at diagnosis
Initial white blood cell count greater than 100,000/mm³
T-cell immunophenotype and CNS involvement at diagnosis

questions.question: A child with leukemia is scheduled to receive the first dose of IV chemotherapy through an implanted port. Which nursing action is the priority before starting the infusion?
options: Allow the child to eat a large meal to avoid nausea
Assess for blood return and ensure patency of the central line
Apply topical anesthetic cream after the infusion has begun
Offer the family a tour of the oncology unit for orientation

questions.question: A 6-year-old with leukemia has an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) of 300/mm³. The provider writes several orders. Which order should the nurse question?
options: Place the child in a private room
Monitor temperature at least every 4 hours
Avoid fresh flowers and potted plants in the room
Obtain rectal temperatures every 4 hours to monitor for fever

questions.question: A child receiving chemotherapy has a platelet count of 18,000/mm³ and suddenly develops a nosebleed. Which nursing action is most appropriate?
options: Pack the nares firmly with cotton-tipped applicators
Tilt the head back and check the throat for blood
Apply continuous pressure to the soft part of the nose and keep the head forward
Administer an NSAID for discomfort and recheck in 30 minutes

questions.question: The parent of a child receiving chemotherapy says, “He always vomits right after treatment.” Which statement by the nurse shows correct teaching about antiemetic use?
options: “We’ll give the anti-nausea medication before chemotherapy and at scheduled times afterward.”
“We only give anti-nausea medicine if your child actually vomits.”
“We’ll wait until he stops eating and drinking, then give the medication.”
“We avoid medications for nausea because they interfere with chemotherapy.”

questions.question: A child on chemotherapy develops painful oral mucositis. Which nursing intervention is most appropriate?
options: Use a soft toothbrush or sponge, offer bland rinses, and avoid alcohol-based mouthwashes
Encourage frequent toothbrushing with a firm-bristled brush after each meal
Offer citrus juices to stimulate saliva and cleanse the mouth
Use lemon-glycerin swabs every 2 hours to cleanse the mucosa

questions.question: A child with Burkitt lymphoma is at high risk for tumor lysis syndrome. Which lab pattern would the nurse recognize as most consistent with this complication?
options: Decreased uric acid, hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, hypercalcemia
Elevated uric acid, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia
Normal electrolytes but elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin
Hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis

questions.question: A child with ALL is receiving high-dose corticosteroids as part of induction therapy. Which parent statement indicates correct understanding of expected side effects?
options: “We should expect significant hair loss while she is on steroids.”
“We’ll watch for increased appetite, weight gain, mood changes, and high blood sugar.”
“Steroids will mostly cause diarrhea and dehydration.”
“These drugs will only cause drowsiness, so we should keep her very active.”

questions.question: The parents of a child newly diagnosed with leukemia say, “We feel like this is our fault somehow.” Which nursing response is most therapeutic?
options: “You shouldn’t feel guilty; many families feel this way.”
“There is nothing you did to cause this; would you like to talk more about what you’re feeling?”
“Let’s focus on the treatment now instead of what caused it.”
“If you had noticed the symptoms sooner, we might have caught it earlier.”

questions.question: A 3-year-old is admitted with a suspected Wilms tumor. Which nursing action is the priority?
options: Measure abdominal girth every shift with the child supine
Avoid palpating the abdomen during assessment
Encourage deep palpation to better define the tumor margins
Place a heating pad over the abdomen to relieve pain

questions.question: A child is diagnosed with a Wilms tumor in the left kidney. The parent asks about preoperative care. Which instruction is most important for the nurse to reinforce with the staff?
options: “Encourage the child to ambulate as much as possible.”
“Offer high-protein meals to promote healing.”
“Monitor urine output strictly every 8 hours.”
“Post a sign above the bed stating: ‘Do NOT palpate abdomen.’”

questions.question: A toddler is diagnosed with neuroblastoma, and the parents ask what this means. Which explanation is most accurate?
options: “It is a benign tumor that usually remains localized in the brain.”
“This is a tumor of the kidney that is typically found early.”
“It always presents with painless lymph node enlargement in the neck.”
“It is a tumor of the sympathetic nervous system that often presents with an abdominal mass.”

questions.question: A school-age child had surgical resection of a posterior fossa brain tumor. Which postoperative assessment finding would be most concerning?
options: Mild headache relieved with acetaminophen
Slight decrease in appetite on the first postoperative day
Repeated vomiting and complaints of a severe headache
Sleepiness immediately after receiving opioid analgesia

questions.question: A nurse is monitoring a child with a brain tumor for increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Which set of findings is most consistent with late signs of increased ICP?
options: High-pitched cry, bulging fontanel, and irritability
Headache, vomiting, and blurred vision
Bradycardia, irregular respirations, and increased systolic blood pressure
Fever, neck stiffness, and photophobia

questions.question: A teen is diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma. Which assessment finding is most characteristic of this disease?
options: Diffuse involvement of the bone marrow at diagnosis
Rapidly growing abdominal mass with bowel obstruction
Generalized petechiae and mucosal bleeding
Painless, firm cervical lymphadenopathy often accompanied by night sweats and fever

questions.question: The nurse is teaching a family about the significance of “B symptoms” (fever, night sweats, weight loss) in Hodgkin lymphoma. Which statement by the parent indicates correct understanding?
options: “Those symptoms are important because they can indicate a more advanced disease and affect treatment planning.”
“Those symptoms only mean our child has a viral infection.”
“These symptoms guarantee that our child is cured more quickly.”
“These symptoms mean that chemotherapy will not be effective.”

questions.question: A 14-year-old with suspected osteosarcoma reports persistent localized pain in the right leg that is worse at night and after activity. X-ray suggests a lesion. Where is osteosarcoma most commonly located?
options: Diaphysis of the small bones of the hands
Metaphysis of long bones, especially around the knee
Skull bones near the cranial sutures
Vertebral bodies of the lumbar spine

questions.question: A 15-year-old had an above-knee amputation for osteosarcoma. Which nursing diagnosis is the highest priority in the immediate postoperative period?
options: Disturbed body image related to loss of limb
Deficient knowledge related to prosthetic use
Acute pain related to surgical procedure and possible phantom pain
Risk for constipation related to opioid use and immobility

questions.question: The nurse is providing teaching to the parents of a child with retinoblastoma. Which statement reflects understanding of a common early sign?
options: “We noticed a white reflex in the pupil on flash photographs.”
“Our child has had constant watery drainage from both eyes.”
“The eyelids are swollen and red with thick discharge.”
“He complains of eye pain only when watching television.”

questions.question: A child with leukemia has a central venous line and develops a temperature of 39.2°C, chills, and malaise. Which nursing action has the highest priority?
options: Administer acetaminophen and reassess temperature in 2 hours
Encourage oral fluids and rest in bed
Obtain ordered blood cultures from all lumens and start broad-spectrum antibiotics promptly
Remove the central line immediately at the bedside

questions.question: A 5-year-old with leukemia and severe thrombocytopenia is on the pediatric unit. Which play activity is safest?
options: Riding a tricycle in the hallway
Playing soccer in the playroom with other children
Participating in roughhousing on the floor with siblings
Quiet board games or drawing at the bedside

questions.question: The parents of a school-age child undergoing maintenance chemotherapy ask if their child can return to school. Which response by the nurse is most appropriate?
options: “Yes, many children can attend school with precautions; we’ll work with the team and school to plan for safety and fatigue.”
“No, your child must be homeschooled until all treatment is completed.”
“Your child can go to school only if no classmates are sick.”
“School attendance is discouraged because it interferes with treatment.”

questions.question: During a follow-up visit after completion of therapy for childhood cancer, the family asks why long-term follow-up is necessary. Which explanation is best?
options: “We mainly need to check that the central line is still functioning well.”
“We only follow children closely if we think the cancer will come back soon.”
“It is required for research and doesn’t really affect your child’s care.”
“Some treatments can cause late effects, such as learning difficulties, heart problems, or second cancers, so regular follow-up is important.”

questions.question: A child with relapsed leukemia is now receiving palliative care. Which nursing statement best reflects the philosophy of pediatric palliative care?
options: “Our goal is to focus on your child’s comfort and quality of life while supporting your family’s wishes.”
“Palliative care means we will stop all medications, including pain medicines.”
“Palliative care is only for the last few hours of life.”
“We will no longer discuss your child’s care plan with you to reduce stress.”

questions.question: The parent of a child receiving intensive chemotherapy asks about routine vaccinations. Which response by the nurse is most appropriate?
options: “We should give all vaccines on schedule to keep your child fully protected.”
“Most vaccines will be delayed during intensive chemotherapy; we’ll plan catch-up immunizations when the immune system recovers.”
“Only live vaccines are safe during chemotherapy.”
“Your child will never be able to receive vaccines again.”

questions.question: A 6-year-old with leukemia is severely immunocompromised. The child’s sibling is scheduled to receive a live attenuated varicella vaccine. What should the nurse tell the parents?
options: “The sibling must not receive the vaccine because it will harm your child with leukemia.”
“You should delay all vaccines for the sibling until chemotherapy is completed.”
“If the sibling develops a fever after the vaccine, your child is fully protected.”
“The sibling can receive the vaccine, but report any post-vaccine rash or illness so we can assess risk to your child.”

questions.question: A child with leukemia and profound neutropenia (ANC 200/mm³) is being discharged home. Which parent statement indicates effective teaching?
options: “We will avoid crowded places, monitor his temperature closely, and call right away if he has a fever.”
“We’ll encourage him to eat fresh salad and raw fruits every day to stay healthy.”
“We’ll allow him to play in the garden soil if he wears gloves.”
“He can continue to share drinks and utensils with his siblings as long as they feel well.”

questions.question: A preschool child with leukemia is scheduled for a bone marrow aspiration. Which nursing intervention best promotes atraumatic care?
options: Apply topical anesthetic cream to the site before the procedure and use age-appropriate distraction techniques
Delay all explanations of the procedure until the child is on the table
Ask the parents to remain outside the room to reduce the child’s anxiety
Avoid using pain medication so the provider can assess the child’s baseline response

questions.question: A child receiving chemotherapy is anemic and fatigued. Which nursing intervention is most appropriate to address activity intolerance?
options: Encourage the child to participate in all activities to “build stamina.”
Restrict all play and visitors to prevent exhaustion.
Plan care to include rest periods between activities and prioritize important tasks when the child has the most energy.
Avoid discussing fatigue with the family to prevent worry.
